revisions.rev:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox person | name = Rosamund Pike | image = RosamundPikeJan2011.jpg | caption = Pike at the premiere of ''[[Barney's Version (film)|Barney's Version]]'' in January 2011 | birth_name = Rosamund Mary Elizabeth Pike | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1979|1|28}} | birth_place = [[London]], England, UK | years_active = 1998âpresent | occupation = Actress | partner = }} '''Rosamund Mary Elizabeth Pike''' (born 28 January 1979) is a British actress. Her film roles include villainous [[Bond girl]] [[Miranda Frost]] in ''[[Die Another Day]]'', [[Jane Bennet]] in ''[[Pride & Prejudice (2005 film)|Pride and Prejudice]]'', Helen in ''[[An Education]]'', Lisa in ''[[Made in Dagenham]]'', Miriam Grant-Panofsky in ''[[Barney's Version (film)|Barney's Version]]'' and Kate Sumner in ''[[Johnny English Reborn]]''.
==Early life== Pike was born in [[London]], England, the only child of concert musicians/opera singers Caroline (nÃ©e Friend) and Julian Pike.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/4987005/Rosamund-Pike-interview.html | work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | location=London | title=Rosamund Pike interview | first=Lucy | last=Cavendish | date=18 March 2009 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> Her father is now a professor at the [[Birmingham Conservatoire]].<ref name=DMail1311882/>
The family travelled across Europe until she was seven, following wherever her parents' performing career took them; as a result, she speaks fluent French and German.<ref name=DMail1311882>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1311882/Rosamund-Pike-From-reluctant-English-rose-Britains-new-screen-queen.html|title=Rosamund Pike: From reluctant English rose to Britain's new screen queen|author=Judith Woods|publisher=Daily Mail|date=24 September 2010|accessdate=2010-11-25}}</ref> Pike won a scholarship to [[Badminton School]],<ref name=DMail1311882/> and while appearing in a production of ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' at the [[National Youth Theatre]], was noticed by an agent who helped her embark upon a professional career.<ref name=DMail1311882/>
After being turned down by every stage school she applied to, she gained a place to read [[English Literature]] at [[Wadham College, Oxford]].<ref name=DMail1311882/> While there, she studied under both [[Bernard O'Donoghue]], the [[Whitbread prize]]-winning poet, and [[Robert J. C. Young]], the eminent post-colonial theorist. During her time at Oxford, Pike was also in a two-year relationship with actor [[Simon Woods]].<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/stage/2009/may/24/rosamund-pike-actress-interview |title=I don't sleep around, if that's what you mean ... Would you like some more cake? |last=Barber |first=Lynn |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=2009-05-24 |location = London}}</ref> She was later to star opposite Woods in ''[[Pride & Prejudice (2005 film)|Pride and Prejudice]]''.
After taking a year off to pursue her acting career, garnering stage experience in [[David Hare (playwright)|David Hare]]'s ''[[Skylight (play)|Skylight]]'', [[Arthur Miller]]'s ''[[All My Sons]]'', and several plays by [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]; she achieved an Upper Second class degree in 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/film/2002/oct/13/features.magazine|title=The name's Pike, Rosamund Pike|publisher=The Guardian|date=13 October 2002|accessdate=2010-11-25}}</ref>
==Career==
Whilst at university, Pike's British television appearances include ''A Rather English Marriage'' (1998), ''[[Wives and Daughters (1999 miniseries)|Wives and Daughters]]'' (1999), and ''[[Love in a Cold Climate (TV serial)|Love in a Cold Climate]]'' (2001), a miniseries based on the [[Nancy Mitford]] novels ''[[The Pursuit of Love]]'' and ''[[Love in a Cold Climate]]''. She appeared as "Sarah Beaumont" in an episode of the series ''[[Foyle's War]].
On graduation, while considering work at [[Waterstone's]] bookshop due to a lack of acting opportunities,<ref name=DMail1311882/> she was offered the role as a [[Bond girl]] and [[Secret Intelligence Service|MI6]] agent assigned to aid [[James Bond]] in ''[[Die Another Day]].'' During the film's release, she appeared in the special show ''[[Bond Girls Are Forever]]'' and, shortly thereafter, the [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] tribute to the ''James Bond'' series.
Pike played Elizabeth Malet in ''[[The Libertine (2004 film)|The Libertine]]'' (2004) co-starring [[Johnny Depp]], which won her the Best Supporting Actress award at the [[British Independent Film Awards]]. In the same year, she portrayed Rose in ''The Promised Land'' (a film about [[Israel]]), and starred as scientist Samantha Grimm in the [[Doom (film)|cinematic adaptation]] of the computer game ''Doom''. She appeared as Jane, the elder sister of Elizabeth (played by [[Keira Knightley]]), in ''Pride & Prejudice''. [[File:Rosamund Pike.jpg|thumb|upright|Pike at the premiere of ''[[Barney's Version (film)|Barney's Version]]'' during the [[2010 Toronto International Film Festival]].]]
Pike has a role in the film adaptation of [[Anne Michaels]]' novel ''[[Fugitive Pieces (film)|Fugitive Pieces]]''. She starred as a successful attorney in the movie ''[[Fracture (2007 film)|Fracture]]'', opposite [[Anthony Hopkins]] and [[Ryan Gosling]]. It was her first experience shooting a movie in Los Angeles.<ref>{{Cite web | last=Lee | first=Michael J | title= A Radio Free Entertainment Exclusive Interview | url=http://movies.radiofree.com/interviews/fracture_rosamund_pike.shtml | publisher=Radio Free Entertainment | accessdate=2007-04-01}}</ref>
Her stage credits include ''Hitchcock Blonde'' by [[Terry Johnson (dramatist)|Terry Johnson]] (in a role requiring her to appear completely nude on stage with only a pair of high heels)<ref>''Mail on Sunday'', 18 October 2009.</ref> and [[Tennessee Williams]]' ''[[Summer and Smoke]]'', both in London's [[West End, London|West End]], and ''[[Gas Light|Gaslight]]'' at London's Old Vic Theatre. Pike has said that she would be happy to do at least one play every year.<ref>{{cite news | last=Bamigboye | first=Baz | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/columnists/article-481665/Rosamund-Pike-A-theatre-girl-heart.html | title=Rosamund Pike: A theatre girl at heart | publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]'' | accessdate=2009-05-26 | date=13 September 2007}}</ref> In 2009, she played the title character in ''Madame De Sade'' during the Donmar's West End season.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/theatre/article-23541568-details/The+man+with+the+Midas+touch/article.do | title=The man with the Midas touch | accessdate=2009-05-26 | date=19 August 2008 | publisher=''[[Evening Standard]]'' | first=Louise | last=Jury }}</ref>
She appeared in the British film ''[[Made in Dagenham]]'' and in the Canadian film ''[[Barney's Version (film)|Barney's Version]]'' where she plays Miriam. In 2010, she starred in a production of ''[[Hedda Gabler]]'' on UK tour.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bamigboye|first=Baz|title=With a little luck Keira Knightly will have sharpened up enough for My Fair Lady|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1212702/BAZ-BAMIGBOYE-With-little-luck-Keira-Knightly-sharpened-My-Fair-Lady.html|accessdate=2009-09-18|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|date=11 September 2009}}</ref>
Pike has recorded voicework for a lead role in the film ''[[Jackboots on Whitehall]]'' and lent her voice to a new series of James Bond audio-books, narrating [[The Spy Who Loved Me (novel)|The Spy Who Loved Me]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rosamund Pike narrates 'The Spy Who Loved Me' for new Ian Fleming audiobooks|url=http://www.mi6.co.uk/news/index.php?itemid=9196&t=mi6&s=news|accessdate=12 January 2011|work=mi6.co.uk|date=12 January 2011}}</ref>
Pike plays the part of Kate Sumner in the 2011 Bond-spoof film ''[[Johnny English Reborn]]'', playing a [[psychologist]] and English's love interest.
==Personal life== While at Oxford, she had a two year relationship with actor [[Simon Woods]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /> She was engaged in 2007 to film director [[Joe Wright]], but they called off the wedding in 2008.<ref>{{cite news | last=Bamigboye | first=Baz | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/showbiz/bazbamigboye.html?in_article_id=478895&in_page_id=1794 | title=Rosamund Pike gets a ring from Mr Wright | publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]'' | accessdate=2009-05-26 | date=7 September 2007}}</ref>
Pike is a skilled [[cellist]].<ref name=DMail1311882/>
